description.narrative: Strengthening the operational and financial sustainability of the national Protected Area System
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

Ultimate Outcomes: 0.1 NPAS operational sustainability measured by average METT score for all PAs based on the following definitions: High (75-100), Medium (55-74), Low (<55). 0.2 NPAS financial capacity measured by Financial Sustainability Scorecard. 0.4 Population of 4 indicator species; 0.4.2 Population of Queen Conch (Strombus gigas). 0.4.2 Population of Black Bill Parrot (Amazona agilis). 0.4.4 Population of Yellow Bill Parrot (Amazona collaria). 0.5 Percentage area of living reef within 10 NPAS monitoring sites. Outcome1: 1.1 Increase in Protected Area Trust Fund (CBF) principal and annual disbursement to NPAS. 1.3 Annual government funding for PAs. 1.4 Annual non-government resources for PAs. 1.5 Local Protected Area Trust Fund 100% established and operational by 2016. 1.6 Number of Protected Areas with Business Plans that reflect NPAS standards. 1.7 Number of Protected Areas with mechanisms to generate revenue at the site level. 1.8 Extent to which operational plan for the PA system financial strategy developed (completed, partially completed, not done); . Outcome2: 2.1 Number of PAs with clearly designated lead and support entity. 2.2 Status of developing drafting instructions for umbrella PA legislation and the supporting legal framework (completed, partially completed, not done); . Outcome 3: 3.1 Increase in PA management effectiveness measured by METT scores. 3.3 Number of PAs with management plans that reflect NPAS management guideline standards. 3.4 Extent to which the M&E system for NPA management developed (completed, partially completed, not done). 3.5 Number of PAs with conservation-based economic activities. 3.6 Status of implementation of Communication Strategy for NPAS (completed, partially completed, not done).

comment.narrative:
Ultimate Outcomes: 0.1 METT score classification: 0 PAs scoring high; 4 PAs scoring medium; and 28 PAs scoring low 0.2 Financial Sustainability score (Part 2) for NPAS is of 53 of possible 225. 0.4 Population of individuals of: , 0.4.2 Queen Conch (Strombus gigas). 0.4.3 endemic Jamaican BlackBird (Nesopsar niggerrimus), 0.4.4 Hawksbill Turtle (Eretmochelys imbricate). 0.5 Living Reef of 3% - 30%. Outcome1: 1.1.1 Protected Area Trust Fund (CBF) principal is $0 and 1.1.2 Annual disbursement to NPAS is $0. 1.3 Annual government funding for PAs is US$4,097,000. 1.4 Annual non-government resources for PAs is US$1,575,987. 1.5 No Protected Areas Trust Fund existing locally. 1.6 No PAs with business plans that reflect NSPA standards. 1.7 One PA with mechanisms to generate Revenue (BJCMNP). 1.8 No Operational Plan for PA system financial strategy available. Outcome2: 2.1 One (1) PA within the NPAS legal agreement designating PA management authority. 2.2 No Umbrella Legislation for NPAS.
Outcome3: 3.1 METT Scores for 28 PAs and 4 Forest Regions as follows: Montego Bay Marine Park – 44; Blue and John Crow Mtn National Park – 72; Negril EPA – 32; Negril Marine Park – 39; Palisadoes-Port Royal Protected Area – 27; Coral Spring-Mountain Spring – 19; Portland Bight Protected Area – 36; Ocho Rios Protected Areas – 19; Mason River protected Area – 54; Bogue Islands Fish Sanctuary – 14; Bowden Fish Sanctuary – 13; Airport Point Fish Sanctuary – 46; Discovery Bay Fish Sanctuary – 34; Bluefields Bay Fish Sanctuary – 33; Orange Bay Fish Sanctuary – 36; Galeon Bay Fish Sanctuary – 30; Salt Harbour Fish Sanctuary – 36; Galleon Harbour Fish Sanctuary – 32; Three Bays Fish Sanctuary – 32; Forestry Northeast – 58; Forestry Southeast – 56; Forestry Northwest – 40; Forestry Southwest – 45; Port Royal and Palisadoes – 52; Black River – 21; Spanish Town – 41; Titchfield Hill – 43; Falmouth – 35; Seville – 74; Rio Nuevo – 17; Mountain River Cave – 44; and Mason River Reserv

Ultimate Outcomes 0.1. METT score classification: High: 2 number of PAs Medium: 9 number of PAs Low: 21 number of PAs 0.2 Financial Sustainability score for NPAS: (Part 2):122 of 225 0.3 No change in area of Closed Broad-leaf Forest: (88,000 hectares) 0.4. Increase in area of Reef: 3% - 30% living 0.5. Distribution and Density of indicator species - No change in Queen Conch: Depth Strata (metres) 0 -10 – 243 conch/hectare 10-20 - 145 conch/hectare 20-30 – 165 conch/hectare
Outcome 1 1.1. Mechanisms for Revolving Fund: Caribbean Biodiversity Fund (CBF) Principal: US$ 3.35 million - CBF Disbursement to NCTFJ: US$100,000-300,000 1.2 Mechanisms in place to generate local funds for the NCTFJ 1.3. Increase on annual government funding for PAs: US$4,500,000-$4,900,000 (12%-20% increase) 1.4. Increase in annual non-government resources: US$1,650,000-$1,891,184 (15%-20% increase) 1.5. Operationalization of the Local Trust Fund by 2016 - Signing of vertical agreement 1.6. 8 PAs with Business Plans that reflect NPAS standards 1.7. Revenue generation in 5 PAs 1.8. Operational Plan for the PA system financial strategy developed
Outcome 2 2.1. 4 Protected Areas within the NPAS with legal agreements designating PA Management Authority 2.2. Drafting Instructions for umbrella PA legislation and supporting legal framework developed 2.3. 1 new coastal and one (1) new marine PA landscape declared and have management plans 2.4. Draft overarching policy for PA management developed (for submission to the Ministry)

Monitoring and Evaluation system for PA management developed 3.5. 3 PAs with conservation-based economic activities implemented 3.6. Communication Strategy for NP

Outcome 1 1.1. CBF Principal of 3.5 million achieved. Remaining balance of funds to be deposited in CBF as soon as Partnership Agreement is signed between CBF and the NCTFJ. CBF Disbursement to the NCTFJ was not achieved under the Project due to the lack of signing of the Partnership Agreement. 1.2 This target was not achieved. Discussions are underway with Government and the private sector. 1.5. Vertical(Partnership Agreement not signed between the CBF and the NCTFJ. Expected to be signed by December 2017. 1.6 Total 8 PAs with Business Plans reflecting NPAS standards 1.8. Operational Plan for the PA system financial strategy completed
Outcome 2 2.3. Target has not been achieved. Documents have been prepared under the project to facilitate declaration of the PAs.
Outcome 3 3.3. 8 PAs with management plans that reflect NPAS management guideline standards completed 3.4. Monitoring and Evaluation system for PA management completed 3.5.5 PAs with conservation-based economic activities implemented (target exceeded) 3.6. Communication strategy for PAs completed

description.narrative: Jamaica Acceded to the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer and the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer, and its London Amendment on 31March 1993. The country subsequently acceded to the Copenhagen Amendment on 6 November 1997, and the Montreal and Beijing Amendments on 24 September 2003. Jamaica is classified as an Article 5 country under the Protocol. Jamaica completely phased out the consumption of Annex A, Group 1 Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) in 2006 and has commenced the process of phasing out consumption of Annex C, Group 1 Hydro-chlorofluor
capital of a political entity

description.narrative: Justice Undertakings for Social Transformation

This compoenent will focus on technical legal assistance and training the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), the office of the Direcotr of Prosecutions (ODPP) and the Court Management Services (CMS) to address a wide range of matters aimed at improving the organizations, management, and service delivery capacity of these institutions. The outputs are: 1.1 Justice reform resources consolidated, streamlined and coordinated 1.2 RBM Tools introduced and practices adopted 1.3 Policy development capacity of the MOJ strengthened 1.4 Participatory monitoring processes integrated in justice reform and moderni
capital of a political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

This component will focus on the strengthening the technical and results based management capacity of the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) to undertake policy development, planning and implementation of justice reform initiatives. The outputs are: 2.1 Standards of professional conduct for prosecutors introduced and implemented 2.2 Standard operating procedures for the exercise of prosecutorial functions and decision-making developed and implemented 2.3 Prosecutorial training and professional development plans and programmes developed and implemented 2.4 Human Resources protocols and strategies devel
capital of a political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration
3.1 Court management and governance strategies developed and implemented 3.2 Measures undertaken to improve the efficiency of the Court System
capital of a political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

Justice Canada InterChange Agreement under the Justice Undertakings for Social Transformation (JUST) Program in Jamaica is to help facilitate funds and management arrangements for Department of Justice Canada
capital of a political entity

The JUST Programme will seek to streamline and improve the legislative drafting process. The Programme will work to strengthen the organization and operations of the Office of the Parliamentary Council (OPC), which is the department with responsibility for writing Jamaica’s statutes and regulations. Outputs are: 4.1 Standard operating procedures for developing legislation and issuing drafting instructions in place 4.2 Changes needed to modernise Law Reform systems and processes identified 4.3 Changes needed to modernise criminal law and practice identified for Cabinet approval
capital of a political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

This component will facilitate involvement of Jamaican non-governmental organizations and will focus on assisting the government to restore public order and trust in the formal institutions of the justice system. The primary focus will be on initiatives aimed at improving the capacity of communities and civil society to participate in justice reform and the promotion of public order
capital of a political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

While assisting the Government in achieving its priorities and in line with the CPD (2012-2016), UNDP Jamaica is strategically supporting the achievement of inclusive and transformational outcomes within its areas of comparative advantage
Provide targeted assistance to build GOJ capacity to deliver on selected national development priorities in line with the ‘Vision 2030 Jamaica: National Development Plan.
capital of a political entity
Health - policy, planning and administration

1) Extent to which the National Strategy for Development Effectiveness developed (fully, partially, not developed) 2) Status of completion of National Consultative Workshops (fully, partially, not done) 3) Percentage of International Development Partners (IDP) in Jamaica consulted for validation 4) Number of International development cooperation summits Jamaica is represented 5) Percent of Implementing Partners assisted in monitoring through validation visits 6) Percentage of quarterly reports received by the CO by the requested deadlines 7) Number of IDP Project Staff trained on RBM 8) Percent of requests from GOJ for technical assistance in M&E fulfilled 9) Percentage of GOJ requests for specialised training for officials facilitated 10) % of participants submitting action plans on applying training for improvement of performance in their MDA 11) Number of initiatives to share knowledge and experience supported 12) Number of international conferences attended by govt officials 13) Number of relevant staff trained in Project Management 14) Percent of relevant entities represented at the high-level sensitization session 15) Number of project proposals developed for submission for funding that relate to government priorities 16) Number of stakeholder consultation sessions conducted that relate to government priorities 17) Number of forums organized to share knowledge and experience on resource mobilization 18) Percentage of proposals successful in securing funding

comment.narrative: 1) National Strategy for Development Effectiveness draft framework developed 2) No National Consultative Workshop for DE Strategy held 3) No International Development Partners (IDP) in Jamaica consulted for validation of Development Effectiveness Strategy 4) No representation at International development cooperation summits by Jamaica 5) No Implementing Partners assisted in monitoring through validation visits 6) 60% of quarterly reports received by the CO by the requested deadline 7) 40 IDP Project Staff trained on RBM 8) No requests from GOJ for technical assistance in M&E fulfilled 9) No GOJ requests for specialised training for officials facilitated 10) No participants submitting action plans on applying training for improvement of performance in their MDA 11) No forums share knowledge and experience held 12) No international conferences attended by govt officials 13) No relevant staff trained in Project Management 14) No entities represented at the high-level sensitization session 15) No proposals developed for submission for funding that relate to government priorities 16) No stakeholder consultation sessions conducted that relate to government priorities 17 No forums organized to share knowledge and experience on resource mobilization 18)No proposals successful in securing funding

Output 1.1: National Strategy for Development Effectiveness in Jamaica developed 1. The National Strategy for Development Effectiveness completed 2. National Consultative Workshop completed
Output 1.2: Monitoring and evaluation capacity of the government and counterparts enhanced 1. 90% 2. 80% of the quarterly reports collected by the CO deadline 3. 80 persons 4. 80% of requests for TA fulfilled
Output 1.3: GOJ officials in Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) have specialised knowledge in strategic areas 1. At least 50% of GOJ requests for specialised training for officials facilitated. 2. Participation in two(2) international conferences per year
Output 1.4: Project Management skills of government and counterparts enhanced 1.Thirty five (35) related staff from government and counterparts trained on Project Management Skills 2.Eighty (80) % of relevant entities represented
Output 1.5: Capacity to localize Sustainable Development Goals within the framework of national development agenda strengthened 1. Min 2 forums per year 2. Agreed activities fully completed 3. Fully established 4. Online training developed 5. At least 1 per year
Output 2.1: CO pipeline of development solutions aligned to current and emerging national development challenges 1. Two project proposals developed for submission funding per year 2. Two sessions per year
Output 2.2: Resource mobilization capacity for consolidating the CO pipeline increased 1. At least 2 forums held to discuss and share knowledge and experience 2. 50% of the proposals secure funding

Output 1.1 The National Strategy for Development Effectiveness completed and validated with having conducted the National Consultative Workshop. Output 1.2 Enhancing Monitoring and evaluation capacity of the government and counterparts continued throughout the year; Both government and implementing partners provided with RBM support; A prototype Monitoring Framework for External Cooperation Management Division of Planning Institute of Jamaica was developed. Support provided to improve the M&E framework of the Community Renewal Programme of government. 100% requests for M&E support fulfilled. Output 1.3 GOJ officials in Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) have specialised knowledge in strategic areas: Two officials were assisted to attend international training/conference/meetings. Output 1.4 Project Management skills training for government was not implemented since the alignment of the training to that of the Public Investment Management System. Output 1.5 Strengthening Capacity to localize Sustainable Development Goals within the framework of national development agenda continued. Social Good Summit to enhance youth participation in Technology innovation was held. Also the launch of the Caribbean CDR and the SDG conference were launched. Online training on Human Rights is being implemented. Output 2.2 Sustainability Plan to replicate Risk Reduction Management Centres at Parish level was developed for resource mobilization.

Output 1.1: Framework for Development Effectiveness in Jamaica strengthened 1.1.4: Two DE information sessions conducted 1.1.5: Sixty persons (50% female) attending DE sessions
Output 1.2: Monitoring and evaluation capacity of the government and counterparts enhanced 1.2.3: 110 persons provided with RBM training 1.2.5: 80% of IPs provided M&E capacity building support
Output 1.3: GOJ officials in Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) have specialised knowledge in strategic areas 1.3.1 At least 50% of GOJ requests for specialised training for officials facilitated. 1.3.2 2 knowledge sharing events of GOJ supported 1.3.3 2 international conferences are attended by GoJ officials
Output 1.5: Capacity to localize Sustainable Development Goals within the framework of national development agenda strengthened 1.5.1: At least one(1) SDG forum per year held 1.5.4: Human Rights training curriculum developed 1.5.5: One (1) GOJ staff facilitated to attend an international human rights event
Output 2.1: CO pipeline of development solutions aligned to current and emerging national development challenges 2.1.1. Two project proposals developed for submission to donors per year 2.1.2. Two stakeholder consultation sessions conducted per year
Output 2.2: Resource mobilization capacity for consolidating the CO pipeline increased 1. At least 2 visibility events fully or partially supported for resource mobilization

Output 1.1: Framework for Development Effectiveness in Jamaica strengthened Draft DE Strategy developed is being re-cast by the Planning Institute of Jamaica. It is partially completed and unlikely to be completed before the end of 2017. 1.1.4: One awareness and validation sessions conducted 1.1.5: 23/26 participants in the DE session were females (88% female) attended DE sessions
Output 1.2: Monitoring and evaluation capacity of the government and counterparts enhanced This is achieved to a great extent. A cross section of project persons (30) from the implementation partners of UN agencies in the government, civil society organizations were provided capacity building opportunity 1.2.3: 110 persons cumulatively (80 in previous years+ 30) provided with RBM training 1.2.5: 100% of UNDP present IPs provided M&E capacity building support
Output 1.3: GOJ officials in Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) have specialised knowledge in strategic areas 1.3.1: 100% of GOJ requests for specialised training for officials facilitated. 1.3.2: No request from GOJ received 1.3.3: 3 GOJ officials facilitated to attend international conferences
Output 1.5: Capacity to localize Sustainable Development Goals within the framework of national development agenda strengthened 1.5.1: One(1) SDG forum per year held (Social Goods Summit) 1.5.4: Two Human Rights training curricula developed 1.5.5: No requests received for international human rights events
Outcome 2: Development options elaborated and available to effectively address current and emerging national development challenges Output 2.1: CO pipeline of development solutions aligned to current and emerging national development challenges 2.1.1. Two project (concepts/proposals) developed (Human Security and Nagoya Protocol) 2.1.2. Two stakeholder consultation sessions conducted.

title.narrative: TNC and BUR to the UNFCCC

description.narrative: Preparation of Third National Communication and Biennial Update Report for Submission to the United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change

title.narrative: TNC and BUR to the UNFCCC

description.narrative: This project will support the preparation of its Third National Communication (TNC) and First biennial Update Report (BUR) for the implementation of its obligations under the UN Framework Convention for Climate Change. This will mainly include conducting national inventory of greenhouse gas emissions, assessing national circumstances, gaps, constraints and financial and technical capacity needs for improving capacity and implementing actions needed to address climate change issues both in terms of mitigation as well as adaptation and reduction vulnerability.
capital of a political entity

title.narrative: Deployment of Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency

description.narrative: This project seeks to advance a low carbon development path and reduce Jamaica’s public sector energy bill through the introduction of renewable energy (RE) and improvement in energy efficiency (EE) in the health sector.

description.narrative: Reintegration and Rehabilitation of Involuntary Returned Migrants in Jamaica

title.narrative: Consultancy to Conduct Study on Involuntary Returned Migrants in Jamaica
Project Coordinator - IRM - Reintegration and Rehabilitation of Involuntary Returned Migrants in Jamaica Project

description.narrative: The main objective of the project is to develop and strengthen the national and local system to enable an increase in the number of deported persons that have access to adequate social services, jobs and livelihood opportunities in Jamaica.
Anti corruption

1.1 Baseline Study and spatial mapping on deported persons completed. 1.2 Deportation Policy completed. 1.3 Minimum Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) on reintegration and rehabilitation of returned migrants completed. 1.4 Reintegration and rehabilitation strategy completed. 2.1 Terms of Reference for National Technical Working Group (NTWG) on Deportation completed. 2.2 Two (2) workshops and six (6) quarterly meetings of the NTWG held; (b)Roadmap and Action Plan for NTWG completed; (c) Thirty percentage (30%) of NTWG members are men. 3.1 Capacity assessments for NGOs completed. 3.2 Thirty (30) participating service providers trained; (b) Fifty (50) IRMs trained; (c) Thirty percent (30%) of participants are women and other vulnerable groups. 3.3 One (1) NGO provided with equipment to strengthen income generation. 4.1 Two (2) stakeholder consultations held to validate framework protocol; (b) Fifty (50) percentage of participants are women and other vulnerable groups. 4.2 Framework and Protocol for tracking the reintegration of returned migrants completed. 5.1 Four (4) training sessions conducted to improve service delivery to returned migrants by local authorities; (b) Fifty percent (50%) of participants are women and other vulnerable groups. 5.2 Two (2) public education materials developed (disaggregated by type). 5.3 Strategy for including reintegration of returned migrants in LSDP process completed. 5.4 Sustainability strategy for Parish safety and Security Committees completed.
